awd_titl_txt: RUI: Seasonal regulation of reproduction in Physcomitrella patens
awd_abstract_narration:
Seasonal information, including temperature and daylength, is used by many plant and animal species to coordinate their reproduction with the environment, so that their offspring are produced at an appropriate time of year. Many flowering plants sense and respond to seasonal cues using a very similar genetic process, suggesting that this process evolved before these species separated from one another. The goal of this project is to better understand the evolution of seasonal regulation by studying how it works in a very distantly related plant, the moss Physcomitrella patens. The results of this research may be pivotal in developing new agricultural crop varieties, especially as seasonal conditions change globally. Undergraduate research students will gain valuable expertise in research through involvement in all aspects of the project. The project will also provide a postdoctoral scientist with training and mentorship in both teaching and research. 

This project uses the moss Physcomitrella patens to probe the evolutionary origin of seasonal regulation in land plants, in order to determine if seasonal regulation evolved prior to the divergence of land plants, or if it arose separately in distinct land plant lineages. A third model would involve conserved upstream pathway components coupled to a novel downstream regulatory module that induces gametangial differentiation in response to proper seasonal cues. In order to distinguish between these alternatives, the project will identify genes involved in seasonal regulation of reproduction in Physcomitrella, utilizing natural variants that differ in their responses to seasonal cues. A combination of whole-genome re-sequencing and RNAseq transcript profiling will be used to identify genes that may be involved in reproductive timing in response to environmental cues. Candidate gene transcript level will be assessed in a wider range of conditions and accessions using quantitative RT-PCR and targeted gene knockouts will be used to assess the functional involvement of candidate genes in seasonal regulation of sexual reproduction. The project will provide significant research training undergraduate student researchers and professional development including presentation at national and international conferences, and will provide an outstanding training opportunity for a postdoctoral scientist interested in undergraduate education.

por.por_cntn:
Plant reproduction is regulated by seasonal changes in daylength and temperature. While the molecular mechanism is understood in many flowering plants, little is known about how this works in non-vascular plants or how the mechanism evolved in the land plant lineage. We sought to uncover the mechanisms that regulate the transition to reproductive development in response to changes in daylength and temperature in the moss P. patens, and make comparisons to flowering plants. We used a combination of transcriptomic and genomic analyses to identify several candidate gene families, many of which are closely related to genes involved in flowering time regulation. Expression of these candidate genes changed dramatically within a day or two following a shift in daylength and/or temperature. We constructed targeted gene knockouts using CRISPR-Cas9 for several candidate gene families, and while seasonal regulation of reproduction was not altered in most mutants, knockouts in one gene family delayed or prevented reproduction under conditions that drive reproductive development in wild type plants. To complement this work, we carried out a genetic screen and identified several mutants that reproduce early in the absence of seasonal cues, when wild type plants are blocked from reproduction. Our work has increased our understanding of the genes involved in seasonal reproduction and suggests that the mechanism in P. patens is largely different from that in flowering plants.

 

The broader impacts of this project involved training undergraduate students in research, preparing a postdoc for a position at a primarily undergraduate institution, and incorporating the research project into undergraduate laboratory courses. Overall 19 undergraduates participated in the research during the academic year and/or during the summer. Students participated in all aspects of the research program, from designing and conducting experiments, to data analysis and presentation of their research in oral and written format, to peer-mentoring of incoming research students. Three students supported by this grant completed undergraduate Honors research theses related to the project and five presented their research at national conferences. Of the 19 undergraduates involved in this research, six are members of underrepresented groups in STEM (first generation and/or underrepresented minority). Overall, approximately 90% of the participants are currently pursuing graduate studies in biology or medical training or intend to do so following post-baccalaureate research experience. Two postdocs were involved in the project, and both co-mentored undergraduate students and taught in at least two courses; one took a position in industry and the other obtained a tenure track position at a primarily undergraduate institution. Aspects of the project were integrated into an upper-level genetics laboratory course, engaging 25 students in authentic course-based undergraduate research experiences related to the project. In addition, the PI developed a new bioinformatics course, training 25 students in genomic analysis using data generated through the project.
